title: Science Fiction and Fantasy Writing Lecture - Introductory Material
summary: Brandon Sanderson's introductory lecture for his science fiction and fantasy writing class at BYU covers his teaching philosophy, the differences between discovery writers and outline writers, the importance of writing advice, the distinction between being a professional and non-professional writer, and the realities of making a living as a fiction writer. He emphasizes the importance of practicing writing, learning revision, and understanding survivorship bias. He also shares a personal story about facing rejection and choosing to continue writing regardless of external success.

concepts.name: Discovery Writer vs. Outline Writer
concepts.description: The contrast between writers who discover their story as they write (discovery writers) and those who plan extensively beforehand (outline writers). Most writers fall somewhere in between.

concepts.name: Professional vs. Non-Professional Writer
concepts.description: The distinction between writing as a hobby and writing as a full-time career, with the understanding that the advice given in the class is tailored toward aspiring professionals but can benefit all writers.

concepts.name: Survivorship Bias
concepts.description: The tendency to overvalue the advice of successful individuals without considering the role of luck or randomness in their success.

concepts.name: Revision
concepts.description: The process of reviewing and improving written work, emphasized as a critical skill for writers to develop.

concepts.name: Writing Groups
concepts.description: Groups of writers who share and critique each other's work. Sanderson provides guidelines for effective participation in writing groups.

section_hierarchy.title: Introduction
section_hierarchy.summary: Welcome to the 2025 lecture series on science fiction and fantasy writing.

subsections.title: Course Overview
subsections.summary: The course will cover introductory material, the instructor's teaching philosophy, discovery writing vs. outline writing, and approaching writing with a professional mindset.

section_hierarchy.title: Class Structure and Recording
section_hierarchy.summary: The class is structured as a lecture series, with a separate application-only class following the lecture. The lectures are recorded and posted on YouTube.

subsections.title: Lecture Format
subsections.summary: Brandon will lecture for about an hour and a half, and answer questions.

subsections.title: Application Class
subsections.summary: A smaller, application-only class follows the lecture series.

subsections.title: Topics Covered
subsections.summary: The course will cover plot, setting, character, and the business of writing, each for two weeks followed by a Q&A session.

section_hierarchy.title: Philosophy of the Class
section_hierarchy.summary: The core philosophy is to treat students as chefs rather than cooks, emphasizing understanding the tools and processes of writing to create desired effects.

subsections.title: Writing Advice
subsections.summary: Writing advice is individual, what works for some may not work for others.

subsections.title: Gardener vs Architect
subsections.summary: Some writers are architects, others are gardeners.

subsections.title: Chef vs Cook
subsections.summary: The goal is to become a chef in writing, understanding the effects of different writing techniques.

section_hierarchy.title: Being a Pro vs. Being a Non-Pro Writer
section_hierarchy.summary: The class will approach writing from the perspective of someone wanting to make a living as a science fiction/fantasy novelist, though all are welcome.

subsections.title: Utilitarian Perspective
subsections.summary: Society often approaches art from a utilitarian perspective, but the primary purpose of art is to enrich the artist's life.

subsections.title: Realities of Professional Writing
subsections.summary: Making a living as a professional novelist is difficult but more attainable than commonly believed.

section_hierarchy.title: Focus on Process, Not Sales (Early On)
section_hierarchy.summary: New writers should focus on writing enough books to learn their process, rather than trying to sell their first books.

subsections.title: Learning Your Scales
subsections.summary: Treat early writing like learning scales on a piano, focusing on practice and development.

subsections.title: Balancing Artist and Business
subsections.summary: While writing, the artist should be in control. After finishing the book, a business-minded persona should take over to exploit the book for profit.

section_hierarchy.title: Revision and Practice
section_hierarchy.summary: Revision is a critical skill to learn. Writing multiple books helps develop this skill and allows for more practice.

subsections.title: Importance of Revision
subsections.summary: Revision is a difficult skill to learn, as important as writing a book.

subsections.title: Over-Revising
subsections.summary: Be aware that constantly revising early chapters leads to no progress.

section_hierarchy.title: Motivation and Survivorship Bias
section_hierarchy.summary: The instructor discusses his motivations for writing, emphasizing the importance of finding personal enjoyment in the process. He also addresses survivorship bias.

subsections.title: Finding Motivation
subsections.summary: Identify personal reasons for writing and track progress.

subsections.title: Survivorship Bias
subsections.summary: Be aware that success stories don't tell the full story. It is important to recognize that success might be random.

section_hierarchy.title: Story of Almost Giving Up
section_hierarchy.summary: The instructor shares a personal story about facing rejection from graduate schools and nearly giving up on writing.

subsections.title: Facing Rejection
subsections.summary: Confronting the decision to keep writing even without external validation.

subsections.title: Embracing Personal Goals
subsections.summary: Deciding to write for personal fulfillment regardless of professional success.

section_hierarchy.title: Questions and Answers
section_hierarchy.summary: The instructor answers questions about writing in the same world, rewriting stories and revision, and writing groups.

subsections.title: Writing in the Same World
subsections.summary: Writing multiple books in the same world, but with different characters is a viable option.

subsections.title: Ideas Are Cheap
subsections.summary: The execution is what really matters.

subsections.title: Rewriting Stories
subsections.summary: Make small revisions.

subsections.title: Writing Groups
subsections.summary: The writing group can ruin your writing.

notes.heading: Course Introduction and Philosophy
bullets: The class is a lecture series on science fiction and fantasy writing at BYU.
The class will cover plot, setting, character, and the business of writing.
The instructor's teaching philosophy is to treat students like chefs, understanding the tools of writing to create desired effects.
Writing advice is individual; what works for some may not work for others.
Most writers are a mix of 'gardener' (discovery writer) and 'architect' (outliner).
The goal is to learn all the tools and processes to create the desired effect in stories.
Writing can be approached as a hobby or as a profession.
The advice given is tailored toward aspiring professionals.
Making a living as a professional novelist is difficult but more attainable than commonly believed.

notes.heading: Focus on Process and Revision
bullets: New writers should focus on writing enough books to learn their process.
Treat early writing like learning scales on a piano, focusing on practice and development.
While writing, the artist should be in control; after finishing, a business-minded persona should take over.
Revision is a critical skill to learn.
The instructor's slowness in selling Elantris was due to a lack of revision skills.
Over-revising early chapters can hinder progress.
The product of writing time is oneself; the time spent writing changes the writer.

notes.heading: Motivation and Realities
bullets: Find personal enjoyment in writing; this is key motivation.
Track writing progress to stay motivated.
Be aware of survivorship bias; the success of others may not be replicable.
The instructor shares a personal story about facing rejection and choosing to continue writing.
It's a good idea to have a backup plan.

notes.heading: Questions and Answers
bullets: Writing multiple books in the same world, but not as direct sequels, is a viable option.
Ideas are cheap; execution is what matters.
Mash ideas together to create practice stories.
To revise, figure out if carrots or sticks or other method works for motivating, bundle the habit with something already a habit.
Make a revision guide and a revision outline, as if working on debugging a program.

notes.heading: Writing Groups
bullets: The writing group can ruin your writing.
If a discovery writer, be careful about taking too much advice until the book is finished.
Do not defend yourself, but listen to the feedback given. Try to be a fly on the wall.
Take the feedback on a book and set it aside for a few months while working on something else, then make a guide to revise it.
If giving feedback, be descriptive and not prescriptive.
